Posts.Content: SonnyB wrote: I could use some advice.  I am 6 months into my journey with extensive bone mets in neck, spine, sacrum, hips, femur.....   My bone scan in June showed no progression and my last tumor markers were down to 22! :) I walk 3-4 miles a day for exercise and to keep my dog from driving me crazy.  A few weeks ago my legs (thigh and down) started tingling (feels like when your limb falls asleep then wakes up) after about 15 minutes of walking and lasts for many hours once I stop.  My onc suggested cutting back on the amount I walk.  Went down to 1-2 miles with no difference in the tingling.  This week I decided to try an aquatic class as there would be no impact on my bones in the water.  After class I had to wait 5 minutes before I could walk due to the extensive tingling. So my question is two-fold.  First, has anyone else experienced anything like this?  Second, should I ask for an MRI or another test.  I am confident it is not new mets due to the low markers but maybe an exixting one is pressing on something????  Just not sure. Some background:  when I was first diagnosed and started treatment I experienced a numbness over most of my body.  I could feel a touch to the skin but not a needle poked in (Or the temperature of the shower!).  My onc and radiologist freaked out, ordered lots of MRIs and had me see a neurologist for a whole series of tests. Everything was came back fine.  The numbness went away as I stopped the steroids I was taking for radiation treatment.  I assume the steroids caused the numbness but my onc thinks that it was an emotional reaction to the situation.  This is why I think she is not concerned about the tingling.  Sorry for the long post.  Any input would be helpful!  Extensive bone mets, neck to femur Dx 2/8/2012, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 1, 1/5 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2015 04:44PM SonnyB wrote: I have wondered about this also. The paragraph Bestbird quotes actually makes sense to me. I read it to say that just because the OS does not appear to have an improvement this is not necessarily true for scenarios in that the OS is a longer time period. That there are too many other factors over a longer period of time after the trial drug has failed to effectively understand the impact the trial drug had on it. Additionally Musa Mayer wrote this is particularly problematic for first line trials in hormone-sensitive MBC, because of the confounding effect of all the subsequent treatments. I take away that I am thrilled with the new drug options we are getting that increases the PFS and will not put too much emphasis on the murky OS numbers.

Posts.Content: Jan 20, 2013 05:14PM SonnyB wrote: Hi all!  I am Sonya, 52 and also married to my high school sweetheart (though it took us until 27 to get married).  We have two great kids, son, 23 living in DC and daughter, 21, senior at University of North Carolina.  The 10 days they were both home for Christmas was the best gift! I've had the opportunity to live in both France (70s) and Mexico (2000/01) and travel alot though my list of 'to-see' places is still large.  I worked in the corporate world until my daughter was born and then was lucky enough to stay home with the kids.  I returned to full-time work five years ago but the company basically closed last May three months after my dx.  After taking the summer off I again have been fortunate to find a 20 hr/wk job that keeps me out of trouble! I love animals but am restricted to a cat and a dog as my DH doesn't share the feeling.  We have a travel trailer and spend most vacations in nature, hilking, kayaking etc.  I also love to curl up with a good book.  How come my list to read is always longer than the time I have?! I was dx Stage IV basically from the start last Feb/Mar.  I have been lucky to have some regression and otherwise stable on Tamoxifen, Xgeva and Lupron.  My plan is to enjoy every day to the max and have no regrets (which means indulging in chocolate!) I am so happy to have found this group.  I try not to talk about my bc around my family too much because it upsets them so it's great to have all of you!

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2012 08:35PM SonnyB wrote: Thanks for the questions Stormynyte!  They are going to make me think on a Sunday night! 1, If you could have a luncheon with any three people (real or fictitious/from any time period/dead or alive), which three people would you choose and why? I love to read so the first person would need to be an author.  I think I would choose Ken Follet as his books can contain suspense, history and/or relationship issues and he just writes well.  The next would be Benjamin Franklin.  He was such a integral part of the beginning of our nation as well as an inventor - it would be fascinating to talk to him.  Finally I would invite my grandfather (mom's dad).  I never met him but from the stories I heard growing up he had a very interesting life, living in India in the early 1900s, running his own quarry in Germany then being put in jail by the Nazis due to his religion. That would be a very interesting luncheon indeed. 2. If given complete freedom to start afresh, what profession would you choose and why? I have often thought I would like to be an architect.  I love seeing how homes are laid out and am always thinking of how the design could have been done better.  I used to go to open houses for fun just to see the floor plan.  However, way back (I'm 52) when I was figuring out what to study I only knew about more traditional paths.  I got a degree in economics and went to work for IBM until I had my kids. 3. What did you do growing up that got you into trouble? I was fortunate to have easy going parents and an older brother who did get into trouble.  That meant whatever I did wasn't anything toublesome comparatively.  However I was a nuisance to my three brothers which resulted in being black and blue for many years as I could not hold my own in a fight!   Looking back, I guess I was busy playing basketballl, riding horses and reading (the only one I still do) that I didn't have time to get into too much trouble. 4. If you could throw any kind of party, what would it be like and what would it be for? Well what I would really like is to throw a 75th birthday party for myself! :)  As that's not going to happen I would love to have a New Years party with all my friends from over the years.  I have moved alot (the longest I have stayed in a house is 6 yrs) and have friends all over the place.  As I am not good at writing (even emails) or calling I don't stay as in touch as I should.  However whenever I do see an old friend it's like no time has passed hence the need for a party that they could all come to. 5. If you could visit anywhere in the world, where would you go and what would you do while there? My goal in life has always been to see as much of the world as possible.  I have been very fortunate to have lived in Paris for 4 years in my teens and having traveled to Europe several times since then (including an amazing summer doing the Eurorail/hostel travel).  We also lived in Mexico about 10 years ago which was a great opportunity for my kids.   The one place I really want to visit but haven't is New Zealand and while I'm there might as well go to Australia.  I love to see the natural beauty of spots I visit and get a feel for the local atmosphere.   My dh and I had been saving and planning to do a lot of traveling upon retirement.  It's frustrating because I know I probably won't make it to retirement age and in the meantime my dh can't take that much time off to do big trips. Bonus question!

Posts.Content: SonnyB wrote: Diagnosed Stage IV on 3/16/12 with bone metastasis (8-10 spots) (5 wks after orig stage II diagnosis).  Started Tamoxifen with Lupron and Xgeva shot right away.  Two years of back pain gone!  Just finished 3 weeks radiation for spot with potential to cause paralysis.  Primary onc wants to now start chemo, Adriamycian based followed by Taxene.  Just got second opinion by research hospital onc.  Her thought is that as long as the Tamoxifen, Lupron and Xgeva work there is no reason to start chemo.  Basically why suffer the side effects while something is working, save it for later.  Has anyone heard of this approach?  Of course I would love to put off chemo but I do want to do everything I can/need to control this beast!  Extensive bone mets, neck to femur Dx 2/8/2012, IDC, 4cm, Stage IV, Grade 1, 1/5 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2012 11:00PM SonnyB wrote: My first Lupron shot was a monthly.  I didn't experience any hot flashes with it.  My next shot was a 4 month shot.  About 2 weeks into it the hot flashes started.  Interestingly the last 3 weeks before the next shot the flashes subsided but immediately came back (worse) after the next shot. I did discuss with my onc the effectiveness of the longer shot as I had read that in some people it might not stay effective for all four months.  She was able to check my estrogen level with my blood work 3.5 months into the shot and was satisfied with the levels. Hope this helps!

Posts.Content: SonnyB wrote: Earlier this year there was a lot of discussion about the pros and cons of a ooph.  I did have one in April after a year on Lupron.  I have not noticed any difference in side effects, only had hot flashes and that remains true. The interesting effect is that my tumor markers have gone down.  I started in the 60s and was down to 22 to 26 on a consistent basis.  Since my ooph my TMs have been 16 and 17.  To me this means that Lupron was not suppressing all of the estrogen.  For me it was the right decision! Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2013 07:32AM SonnyB wrote: I am on Xgeva not Zometa but I think the resulting effects seen in scans would be similar. My understanding is that the bone scan cannot tell the difference btw healing bone and tumors. Therefore when I have bone scans my onc is not concerned with area we know there is/has been a tumor but is looking for new areas that show up. It seems like your mom has new areas of activity. If your onc isn't concerned about these my question would be why did he order the scan? What would be a concern to him? I do get a PET about every 8 months now so my onc can see the tumor activity and better know what is going on.

Posts.Content: Jan 6, 2016 03:57PM SonnyB wrote: I was diagnosed stage 2b to start. Had lumpectomy but then had a PET before I started chemo. It turned out that I had extensive bone mets. My onc wanted to still do aggressive chemo (I was 51 at the time) but multiple second opinions suggested to start with hormonals. I choose to start with hormonals - Tamoxifen (w/Lupron to shut down my ovaries). The tamoxifen gradually stopped all of the cancer in my bones and worked for 3 1/2 years. Just this fall a bone scan showed 2 new small spots so I have switched to Letrozole. I know that I will eventually go through the chemo options but for almost four years now the homonals have kept the cancer at bay with NO side effects. Obviously we all respond differently to these drugs and that is why there really is no clear cut path on which road to take. Good luck with you decision.
